text:
JAMES FALCONER: My
name is James Falconer.
I work for The Boundary.

I operate out of
our New York office.

The Boundary is a creative
visualization studio.

So what we do is we
create a CGI-based content

for predominantly the
real estate industry.

And what we do is we
bring to life ideas

and concepts and projects
that haven't been realized.

So for example, we'll be
creating marketing content

for developers to
sell their buildings

off plan, ahead of them
actually being built.

That's usually in the form of
renderings, animations, films,

and real-time virtual
tours as well.

Unreal Engine is one of
our absolute core softwares
within the business.

It's the basis of a
lot of our services
that we provide to our client.

We've seen a massive uptick in
the use of virtual production
as part of our service.

So we'll use virtual production
to create marketing films

for real estate
projects predominantly.

And we're using Unreal
Engine to create

incredible photorealistic
CGI backgrounds

that we can then
place live actors
and actresses into the space.

That's something that we see
becoming much more popular

over the coming years,
and we certainly

anticipate that that will
be a larger and larger part
of our portfolio.

Another very large part of
the work we do at the moment
is in digital twins.

So we use Unreal
Engine to create

incredibly complex, large-scale,
fully real-time twins

for some massive projects
around the world.

Recently, we were working on
a really unbelievable project

designed by SHoP
architects, and the project

was for the Mercedes-Benz
Residences in Miami.

And on that project, we
working with Ryan Serhant,

who's quite a famous star from
Netflix show Owning Manhattan.

So using virtual
production, we were

able to shoot Ryan
arriving at the building,

moving through the
lobby, arriving

through the amenity spaces
into one of the apartments,

and then out onto a balcony,
where he could look out
over the city skyline of Miami.

The breakthrough moment for us,
and also quite a breakthrough

moment for our industry, where
we saw virtual production

used to that incredible
effect for the first time.

The film has been
incredibly well received,

but we like to think some of
the virtual production work we
did played a big part in that.

The skill sets, in
terms of real time,

that we need within
our business,

it's actually quite broad
because we go from the macro
to the micro.

So we have project teams working
on large city-scale digital

twins, which requires
a huge amount of model

optimization, incredible
knowledge of level of detail.

And we also have teams working
on the real-time real-time

virtual tours of
apartments and condos,

and that requires
quite a different skill

set, which is much more
about texturing, detail,
control of light.

And then we also have our
virtual production team,

which, again, is a
whole other skill set.

How are we
integrating the models

with the cameras
and the movements.
How are we planning our shoots?

How are we building our
scenes in Unreal Engine

to best make use of the virtual
production capabilities?

One area is going to become
significantly important,

and I would encourage people to
maybe lean into and try and get

a good technical
understanding of,

is how do we bring these
experiences online?

What we're seeing
now is more and more

demand for people being able
to access that content online,
on the move, on a mobile device.

And I would encourage
students and people

entering the industry to
really wrap their heads around

that because that's
an area that they'll

be able to add a lot of
value to going forward.

My advice to students would
to be as curious as possible.
Find work that inspires you.

Find studios that
inspire you, follow them.

Just keep looking,
keep learning.

And that applies
throughout your career.

Make sure you're always
just looking around
at what other people are doing.

Try and learn, be
inspired, and stay curious.
